text: I think a model involving a projection from a higher dimensional parameter space to a lower dimensional space of observables is by definition non-identifiable because this function is not invertible. Think vision, bad data compression, etc. On multi-modality, ODE-based systems and neural ODE systems usually have fairly multi-modal posteriors.

elements.text: I think a model involving a projection from a higher dimensional parameter space to a lower dimensional space of observables is by definition non-identifiable because this function is not invertible. Think vision, bad data compression, etc. On multi-modality, ODE-based systems and neural ODE systems usually have fairly multi-modal posteriors.

text: Anything in gen for this <@UB4KJ0X9D>  or <@UL59KHYPQ>? Seems like vision would be a good gen usecase

elements.text: ? Seems like vision would be a good gen usecase

text: <@UDGT4PM41> we definitely work with multimodal distributions — lots of ways you can handle, including custom MCMC proposals (including reversible jump), annealed importance sampling, particle filters with rejuvenation... the right approach will depend on the problem! But we don’t have anything 100% automated that you can throw at a multimodal posterior and get good results from (and I don’t think the stats community at large does either)
